member.name: T:Smrf.AppLib.BinaryHeap`2
member.summary:
Represents a binary heap.
The heap stores zero or more items, each of which has a unique key and a value that corresponds to the key. The items are ordered by value. The order can be either descending (for a max heap) or ascending (for a min heap), depending on the IComparer interface passed to the constructor.

member.name: T:Smrf.GraphicsLib.ColorUtil
member.summary: Utility methods for working with colors.
member.remarks:
This class adds functionality to the System.Drawing.Color class. A better design would have a new ColorPlus class inherit from Color, with new methods added to ColorPlus, but because the Color class is sealed, that isn't possible.
All methods are static.

members.member: Saturation to use for all colors. Saturation ranges from 0 to 240, where 0 is grayscale and 240 is the most saturated.
Maximum luminance to use. Don't get too close to white, which would prevent bright colors from being distinguishable from one another.

member.name: M:Smrf.GraphicsLib.ColorUtil.GetUniqueColor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets one of a series of unique colors.
member.param: The index of the unique color within the series. Must be greater than or equal to zero.
The total number of unique color within the series. Must be greater than zero.
member.returns: One unique color in a series.
member.remarks:
This method is meant to be called times to obtain a series of unique colors.
This method cycles through a fixed set of colors, then repeats the set as many times as necessary with increasing luminance components.
The number of colors in the fixed set is .

member.returns: true if contains a valid color.
member.remarks: If contains a valid color, the converted color gets stored at and true is returned. Otherwise, false is returned.

member.name: M:Smrf.AppLib.PersistableStringDictionary.PopulateDictionary(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.String},System.String)
member.summary: For derived classes only. Populates an existing collection of key/value pairs from a string.
member.param: The dictionary to populate.
The collection as a string. Can be empty but not null.
member.remarks: This is meant for use only by derived implementations of FromString(). It's a workaround for the fact that if DerivedClass is derived from PersistableStringDictionary, the DerivedClass.FromString() method can't call the base-class FromString() method and cast the return value to a DerivedClass object. Such a cast throws an exception at runtime. Instead, the derived method can create its own DerivedClass object, then populate it using this method.

Call for each document that contains terms that need to be counted. When done, call to calculate the salience of each term within all the documents, then use to get a collection of the terms that were counted in all the documents.
By default, URLs and punctuation are skipped when terms are counted. Use the property to change this behavior.

member.name: T:Smrf.AppLib.WordCounter
member.summary: Counts words in one or more documents.
member.remarks:
Call for each document that contains words that need to be counted. When done, call to calculate the salience of each word within all the documents, then use to get a collection of the words that were counted in all the documents.
If you use the single-argument constructor, then when words are counted, the words "B" and "b" are considered the same word, and the string is always in lower case.

member.name: T:Smrf.AppLib.WordPairCounter
member.summary: Counts pairs of words in one or more documents.
member.remarks:
Call for each document that contains word pairs that need to be counted. When done, call and to calculate the salience and mutual information of each word pair within all the documents, then use to get a collection of the word pairs that were counted in all the documents.
When word pairs are counted, the pairs "A B", "A b", and "a b" are all considered the same pair. If you call for each of these strings, then will return a collection containing a single object, with its property set to 3.
The and strings are always in lower case. The order of the two words is significant, so that "a b" and "b a" are counted as two separate word pairs.
